questiontext.text:
Sometimes it is necessary to apply the formula more than once, as the next Example shows.

Example

Find \({\displaystyle\int 2x^2 e^{-x} \, \mathrm{d}x}\).

Solution

We let \(f=2x^2\) and \(g=e^{-x}\). Then \(\dfrac{\mathrm{d} f}{\mathrm{d} x}=4x\) and \({\displaystyle\int g \, \mathrm{d}x} = -e^{-x}\)

Using the formula for integration by parts we find

\({\displaystyle\int 2x^2 e^{-x} \, \mathrm{d}x = 2x^2(-e^{-x})-\displaystyle\int 4x(-e^{-x}) \, \mathrm{d}x = -2x^2e^{-x}+\displaystyle\int4xe^{-x} \, \mathrm{d}x}\)

We now need to find \({\displaystyle\int4xe^{-x} \, \mathrm{d}x}\) using integration by parts again. We get

\begin{eqnarray*} \int 4xe^{-x}\ \mathrm{d} x&=&4x(-e^{-x})-\int4(-e^{-x})\ \mathrm{d} x\\ &=&-4xe^{-x}+\int 4e^{-x}\ \mathrm{d} x\\ &=&-4xe^{-x}-4e^{-x}\end{eqnarray*}

Altogether we have

\({\displaystyle\int 2x^2e^{-x} \, \mathrm{d}x} = -2x^2e^{-x}-4x e^{-x}-4 e^{-x}+c = -2e^{-x}(x^2+2x+2)+c\)
